text: All right.

So we will go ahead
and get started.

I am happy to introduce
Dr. Pat Burchat, who

is going to be speaking
with us about both physics
and engineering physics.

And we will have one
more professor who
will be joining us momentarily.
Pat.
OK, great.

So I'm going to start with
an introduction of myself.

And then I'm going to ask
a few questions about you,

OK, so I can learn a little
bit about some of the courses
that you're taking now.

So, as you heard, my
name is Pat Burchat.

People often ask how do
you pronounce my last name,

so it's like a little
bur and a cat, OK?
So Burchat.
And I serve in--

as chair of physics
advising, so advising
in the physics department.

And I'm co-director of
engineering physics.

And I'm an instructor
in physics 61.

Actually, I have autumn 2020
there, also in 2021, and 2022.
And-- Hi, Mark.
Great.
Good timing.

And a little bit
personally about me.
So I grew up in Canada.

And I often say I grew
up in a very large family
in a very small town.

At about 1,200 people, it still
has about 1,200 people in it.

And my eight siblings and I
were all first-gen high school
graduates.

Our parents didn't
graduate from high school.

And so it shows that
education is really powerful,

that you can go from parents
with no high school graduation,

to ending up a professor at the
physics department at Stanford.

And my research, for most
of my research career,

I did accelerator-based
particle physics.

So that's a picture of the
two-mile long accelerator
at SLAC, the thing on the left.

And I came here actually to
Stanford for graduate school

to do experimental
particle physics.

And I did that for
about 25 years or so.

And then I kind of had
the option at that point,

I would have to
go to CERN, which

is the big complex in Europe,
to continue particle physics.

And particle physics was
a really mature field
at that point.

And I wanted to be
like a student again,
get back on the learning curve.

And so, I actually
switched fields
to observational cosmology.
And it might seem like, Wow.

That is kind of different,
going from particle physics,

understanding the things
at the smallest scale,

to the universe on
the largest scale.

But in both cases,
we use detectors

that have billions of channels
of readout, statistical
techniques.
And the questions are the same.
What is the universe made of?

And how does that all
that stuff interact?

OK, so now I'm working
on a telescope project.

The telescope is actually
under construction right

where I am standing in
that picture on the right.

That's in Chile, a mountaintop
in Chile, about 9000ft up.

And right now there is
about a few hundred million

dollar telescope there
completing construction.

We're about to start
commissioning it, and then
taking data.
So that is enough about me.
Oh, one other thing.

My undergraduate degree
was in engineering science

at University of Toronto, which
is like engineering physics.

And when I came
to Stanford, there

was no engineering
physics program.

And I would be
advising students.

And some of them
like, well, I don't

know if I want to do
physics or engineering.

And those were
pretty different, OK.

And I thought we need an
engineering physics program.

So a number of us got together
in the School of Engineering

and Physics, and came up with
the engineering physics program
about 15 years ago, or so.

And Mark Capelli
is my co-director.

And so, do you want to go
ahead and introduce yourself?

And we've got these
animations going here, so.
OK.
Oh, good, you can hear me.
Thanks, Pat.

Well, I didn't plan on
saying much about myself.

But I came here
about 35 years ago.

Also from the
University of Toronto.
So I'm also Canadian.
Lots of Canadians.

In fact, Jim Plummer
was a Canadian

from the University of Toronto,
former Dean here at Stanford.

I think Electrical Engineering
University of Toronto, Plummer,
I think.

So I grew up in a small
town in Southern Ontario.

And parents were
immigrants from Italy.
All my cousins worked on farms.
I worked on farms.

I didn't have a plan
to go to college.

And when I was in
high school, that

was in a vocational high
school, one of my teachers

said, Mark, have
you ever thought
about going to university?
And I said, not really.
And he said, well, you should.

And so I switched high
schools to a high school
that was more--

that was better in preparing
you for university.
Went to McGill University.

Didn't intend to study
physics originally,

but I thought physics was hard,
so I guess I should try it.

And was admitted to
the physics department

at the University of Toronto
for Graduate Studies,

but I chose aerospace
engineering instead,

and did a PhD in a
fusion-related subject.

Why aerospace
engineering and fusion?

Well, if we ever want to explore
the outer planets and planets

beyond our solar
system, you're going

to need fusion energy
to do that properly.
And so that was my history.
I show a photograph here.

Down to my left is the
National Ignition Facility.

It's a fusion experiment
to demonstrate
inertial confinement fusion.

And an engineering physics
graduate, Chris Young,

is responsible for setting
a record in August, broke
the Lawson criteria for fusion.
And that's a great thing.

And in fact, his
advisor was also

a student of mine in mechanical
engineering at the National
Ignition Facility, Nathan Mason.

He went through
undergraduate ME.

I'll tell you more about that
later, mechanical engineering.

And then stayed on for his
PhD in mechanical engineering
as well.

Up to the top left of my
photograph is a plasma source.
It's called the Z-pinch.

It's a source that
we actually run here,

unlike experiments that we do at
the National Ignition Facility.

A few of my students are
involved in the experiments,

designing the experiments
that we carry out there.

And on the big laser
facility in omega,

we also have a machine for

very dense plasmas,
also fusion-related.
And that's all about me.

Should I?

So what is-- so today
we're going to--

Pat and I are going
to share this.

I'm going to say a little bit
about engineering physics.

She's the co-director
as well, but then she's

going to carry on afterwards
and talk about physics more
specifically.
What is engineering physics?

Engineering physics
brings together

three disciplinary
areas, as shown here,
math, physics, and engineering.

You might say, well,
doesn't engineering
also use math and physics?

That's true, but you get
a little bit more math

and a little bit more physics
in engineering physics.

And then you specialize
in a particularly--

an area of interest in
engineering that you're
particularly interested in.

It prepares you
to, as we say here,

tackle problems that
are at the forefront--

multi-disciplinary
problems that are

at the forefront of technology,
that we might-- in engineering
we might not yet be working on.

So that's where you go
with engineering physics.

In engineering physics,
you could specialize
in several areas of focus.

This is now, once you get
into the upper division,

where you've already done
the core studies that you're

required to do in
physics and mathematics

and then you specialize
in one of many areas.

And one of those areas
is renewable energy.

And there we ask
questions like, how can we

use the combination of
physics, engineering

to solve, or at least address
some of the big problems

that we have in renewable
energy, for example.
That's a hot topic right now.

It's a popular one for many
of our engineering physics
students, right?

Another area of interest
is-- and this is kind of

coupled in some ways, is the
specialty we call material
science and engineering.

And it asks the
questions on how you

can design new materials that
advance the performance of some

of the technologies
that you might

find in the renewable
energy specialty, all right.

And this is a hot
area now, too, right?
Battery technology.

If we really want
to get to a point

where we can reliably use
high-efficiency storage

methods, like batteries,
we need new materials.

The materials that we use
now, lithium-ion batteries,

nickel-cadmium, they're
just not going to cut it.

They're not going
to work to the level

that we expect them to work if
we want to be able to displace

other technologies, like
internal combustion engines,
for transportation, for example.

Another area that
students specialize

in when they study
engineering physics
is electromechanical systems.

And many of the
courses related to this

are in my department,
mechanical engineering.

There you ask questions like how
can you combine physics, math,

and engineering to design
the next generation
of smart products.

These are products that exploit
things like mechanical systems,
dynamic systems, robotics.

And all of that
needs to be managed

by electric circuits, right,
processors, microprocessors,
and computers.

Aerospace physics is
a relatively new one.

I think it's only about
four years old now
in our specialty list.

Another popular one for some
of our undergraduate students,
all right.

How can we better
the understanding

of the space environment
and the physics

associated with it to design
new space vehicles and control

space vehicles in a way that
gets us places, and carries out

certain tasks in
space, all right?

Eventually, for
example, we're going

to run out of certain
resources on Earth,

or it's going to become
too expensive to mine
those resources.

Examples like we're going to
have to develop technologies

to get us to other places,
other planets, or the moon,

or even to asteroids
and mine resources

that are going to help
us make those batteries,

the new materials that
are going to be needed
for the new batteries, right?

So that's a popular one,
growing in popularity.

And then there's one that we
call computational science,

another, relatively new one that
might be about eight years old.

And we ask questions
like how can we

combine the computational theory
and algorithms, many of which,

for example, we
use in gaming now.

But they're very
powerful algorithms

to solve big
problems in science,
and also to manage big data.
So that's a popular specialty.

And finally, one that we
introduced a few years ago,

quantum science specialty,
and that one, of course,

quantum systems are
now, they're not

just things that you read about
in textbooks anymore, right?

You could imagine engineers
beginning to build computers

out of systems that operate
at the quantum scale, right,
the quantum scales.

Cryptography, as you know,
exploits quantum entanglement.

And all of these
might be something

that you see in a
physics class now,

but eventually,
in the next decade

or so, you're going to see more
and more of that cross over
to the engineering side.

So those are the
disciplinary areas
of engineering physics, and--

oh, I think I'm going to now
turn it over to you, Pat,
right, to talk about.
Yeah, You got this.
OK.

And there was one in the
corner of the previous slide.

Yeah, but that's OK.
Yeah, biophysics, but there's--
Oh, the biophysics

But there's nothing
about it because it'll
show up in physics, OK.
And so I'll pick that up then.

So how do we contrast
engineering physics
with physics?

So physics really emphasizes--
and this is actually

an essential part of
engineering physics,

too, that physics emphasizes a
first-principles understanding
of the universe.
What do we mean by that?

In physics, we try to come up
with mathematically consistent
predictive theories, OK?

A theory that you can
make a prediction from,

that describes the
universe on all scales,
from the tiniest to the largest.

And, in addition, we want
to understand the universe

by doing observations
and experimentation

to test the predictions, and
hopefully, and often, discover
new physics.
OK?

So that's actually
the most exciting part

is not just verify what we
predicted, but perhaps find
something new.

And then, through something
like engineering physics,

we can apply it to come
up with new discoveries.

So we have in physics
what we call pathways.

So in engineering
physics they're

called specialties, in physics
they're called pathways.

In both cases, we
have seven of them.

It turned out this
happened to be.

And the first one that I
feature here is biophysics.

So biophysics
answers the question,

how can we use techniques
developed in physics

to advance our understanding
of biological systems?

So, for example, this
little movie here,

which I think will play,
shows some real-time imaging
of a brain in a mouse.

And you see those little
flashes of light there.

So basically, they're imaging
all these little flashes.

In the end, they will be able
to stack all the flashes up

and get a really high-resolution
picture of this brain, OK?

And all the techniques
that are being

used there to make these
things flash, what is it,

the imaging and stuff,
relies on a lot of physics.

And so it's using
physics techniques

to understand
biological systems.

The bottom one is a
retinal prosthesis,

so artificial retina, that
is being developed to replace
damaged retina cells, OK.

And so obviously, there's
a lot of physics in there.

The person who does that,
Daniel Palanker, his background

was all in laser physics and
fundamental atomic physics.

And then he was
also very interested
in medical applications.

And, at one point, he actually
had a bit of an eye injury

in a laboratory, and ended
up in the emergency room
at Stanford University.

And ended up talking to
the head of-- the new Chair
of Ophthalmology there.

And that's how he
started this program.

So he is now this world-class
program in that area.

Then another specialty or
pathway is astrophysics.

So an astrophysics we'll
ask questions like,
how are stars born?
How do they evolve in time?

And also, a lot of
studies of black holes.

Can we detect and
study black holes.

So one of the ways a star,
or set of stars, might die.

And so on the left image for
the astrophysics part there,

that is an image of
gravitational waves,

just a kind of artist's
rendition, going through space.

And this is what was detected
by that detector called LIGO
from merging black holes.

And then the one on the
right, you may recognize,

this was an image of
radiation around a black hole.

And this was done
within the last year.

So we're actually finding out
a lot about black holes now.

Other questions could be how
do galaxies form and evolve?
What is dark matter?
We don't know.
We know it's there.
We don't know what it is.
What is dark energy?
We know it's there.

We don't know what it is, what
is the origin of the universe,

and how is the universe
itself evolving?

So those questions
are cosmology.

And that's the kind of
thing I'm working on now.

Another pathway is computational
physics and data science.

So this picture on the left
is a picture of a textbook.

The authors-- I know
all the authors.

They're all astrophysicists
and cosmologists.

But it's called Statistics,
Data-Mining, and Machine

Learning in Astronomy,
a practical Python

guide for the analysis
of survey data.
It's a fantastic textbook.

It's actually online,
and they are always

updating it, their Python
notebooks and everything
to go with it.

So we use a lot of computational
techniques in physics.

And the thing on the
right, you might say, hah,

that looks like
black holes again.

So that is a simulation
of merging black holes.

So that's an example of what
computational physics would
be applied to.

And then geophysics,
understanding the Earth

at all levels, is
basically physics, OK?

I mean, there's chemistry as
well, but a lot of physics.

And so these are just two images
that I found that I thought
were kind of representative.

The one on the right
represents the magnetic fields

of the Earth between the times
when the fields will flip.

I don't know if this,
but every, roughly, I

think 10,000 years or so, the
north and south Pole flip, OK?

So there, with physics,
you can actually

calculate what might
happen during that time.

And will we be able to keep
up with that change, the way
the birds and the bees do?

Because they use
magnetic fields a lot.

The thing on the left is weather
patterns and circulations
and stuff.

And actually, for anyone
here who's in Physics 61,

we were mentioning
the Coriolis force.

And I was saying it
produces these things called

Hadley cells in the
atmosphere and everything.

That's all physics, OK,
understanding those circulation
patterns.

So a lot of physics
and geophysics.

Number 5 of 7,
mathematical physics.

So this is related to
theoretical physics,

but theoretical
physics is like, how

do you discover new
theories in physics?

Mathematical
physics is, what are

the mathematical foundations
of theoretical physics?

And how does math inform
physics and physics inform math?

OK, sometimes math-- physicists
are winning math prizes

because they end up
being able to make

big leaps in mathematics
using physical reasoning.

So if you like both
math and physics,

then the mathematical
physics pathway can be good.

And then quantum science and
information, you might say,

did I just hear that
in engineering physics?

So in engineering physics,
it was quantum science

and engineering, so maybe
more a little more emphasis

systems.

And here, quantum science and
information, a little bit more

on what is the fundamental
nature of information

at the quantum level because
the information is not

carried in bits, that
could be a 0 or a 1,

but instead you might
have heard of qubits,

so a quantum bit that has a
certain probability of being
a 0 and a 1.
And
Mark mentioned entangled states.

OK, so entanglement in
kind of information there.

These are the
kinds of things one

might study in quantum
science and engineering--
and information.

But there'd be high overlap
with quantum science
and engineering.

And a lot of physicists
do experimental physics.

And will also be working
on applications that are
relevant for quantum computing.

And then finally,
physics education.

And so, how can we
improve student learning

of physics concepts through
improved pedagogical
techniques?

And you might say, well,
why isn't that just
in the School of Education?
OK, why is this in physics?

Well, in physics, we actually

The experiments
are our classrooms.

And physics education

And so, at Stanford, we've

and so there's a pathway

OK, so seven specialties,
seven pathways, that

give you a sampling

And so this is a

If you're interested, what do
physics and engineering physics
students do after they graduate?
All kinds of stuff.

A lot of students will go on
for higher education, so either
a master's degree or a PhD.

In physics, it's
probably about 60%

of our students go on
and get a PhD in physics.

In engineering physics,
it might be 40% to 50%,
OK, but not always in physics.

Like physics will go
over into engineering,

engineering physics will
go physics or engineering.

Then a number of students
will go into the industry
or the private sector.

So examples are data science
engineering, startup founders.

Last time, we looked at the

like I think we're looking

I think none had

Of the engineering
physics majors,

I think out of 30 or so,
3 had started companies.

OK, so there definitely
is kind of like a choice
going on there.

Then in the upper right,
a way of thinking.

So public service,
policy analyst,

think tanks, consulting
firms, they often

love physics or
engineering physics majors

because you're kind of trained
to think about any problem,

like not just in a
particular domain.

Also, teaching, OK, we had
the physics education there.

Even our graduate students
sometimes working on their PhD,

they realize that what
they love most about

it is serving as teaching
assistants for you,

OK, the undergraduates, and

Or professional degrees
like medicine or law.

Actually, physics and

do really well on
the MCAT and LSAT,

OK, the standardized test

They're self-selected
they're ones who are

But it is a good

Also, we have majors

OK, so this is not

They have fun doing physics,

Being involved in research

As soon as you are interested.
We welcome freshmen to apply.

We require physics 41
